dcterms:creator: D. Campbell
J. Kelly
dcterms:description: The Common Settings refer to a framework in social choice theory where preferences and decisions are represented as ranked lists or committees.
dcterms:title: Common Settings

dcterms:creator: D. Campbell
J. Kelly
dcterms:description: The Arrovian framework is a theoretical model in social choice that deals with the aggregation of individual preferences into a collective decision.
dcterms:title: Arrovian framework

dcterms:creator: C. Dwork
R. Kumar
M. Naor
D. Sivakumar
dcterms:description: Rank aggregation methods for the web involve techniques to combine multiple rankings into a single ranking, often used in search engines and recommendation systems.
dcterms:title: rank aggregation

dcterms:creator: S. Brams
P. Fishburn
dcterms:description: Approval voting is a voting method in which voters can express approval for as many candidates as they like, and the candidate with the most approvals wins.
dcterms:title: Approval voting

dcterms:creator: E. Elkind
P. Faliszewski
P. Skowron
A. Slinko
dcterms:description: Multi-winner voting refers to electoral systems where voters select multiple candidates, and various rules determine how these candidates are elected.
dcterms:title: Multi-winner voting

dcterms:creator: L. Bartholdi
W. Hann-Caruthers
M. Josyula
O. Tamuz
L. Yariv
dcterms:description: The Veto voting rule allows voters to veto certain candidates, and the candidate with the least vetoes wins.
dcterms:title: Veto

dcterms:creator: L. Bartholdi
W. Hann-Caruthers
M. Josyula
O. Tamuz
L. Yariv
dcterms:description: The Copeland voting rule assigns points based on head-to-head matchups, rewarding candidates for each opponent they beat.
dcterms:title: Copeland

dcterms:creator: L. Bartholdi
W. Hann-Caruthers
M. Josyula
O. Tamuz
L. Yariv
dcterms:description: Maximin voting selects the candidate with the highest minimum score based on pairwise comparisons.
dcterms:title: Maximin

dcterms:creator: M. Schulze
dcterms:description: The Schulze method is a ranked voting system that identifies the winner based on the strength of paths in a directed graph representing preferences.
dcterms:title: Schulze

dcterms:creator: L. Bartholdi
W. Hann-Caruthers
M. Josyula
O. Tamuz
L. Yariv
dcterms:description: The Single Transferable Vote (STV) is a voting system that allows voters to rank candidates in order of preference.
dcterms:title: STV (Single Transferable Vote)
